message_text: Redirecting behaviour
PLH - Internal - Update incomplete toolkits
@fields.from_theme
Try to redirect. Stop it before it starts! When your children get restless, you can distract them with something interesting or fun: "Come, let's play a game together!"
@fields.type_of_media
@fields.child_nickname
Here's a video that helps you redirect @fields.child_nickname's behaviour when they misbehave.
Here's a video that helps you redirect your child's behaviour when they misbehave.
@fields.child_nickname
Here's an audio message that can help you redirect @fields.child_nickname's behaviour when they misbehave.
Here's an audio message that can help you redirect your child's behaviour when they misbehave.
@fields.child_nickname

Keep it positive. It is normal to want to say something about @fields.child_nickname's negative behaviour, like “Don’t whine,” or “Stop running in the house.” Instead, just say something that you want @fields.child_nickname to do, like "Speak with a calm voice," or "Remember to walk inside the house."

Keep it positive. It is normal to want to say something about your child's negative behaviour, like “Don’t whine,” or “Stop running in the house.” Instead, just say something that you want your child to do, like "Speak with a calm voice," or "Remember to walk inside the house."
@fields.parent_baby
If your baby is starting to crawl or walk, you can also redirect them by physically picking them up and focusing their attention on something else interesting. Use a lively and cheerful voice!
Here is a comic that shows how you can use redirect!

Child: “Give it to me!”

(1)

Teen: “I had it first!” 

(2)

Parent: “Cameron and Billy, come and help me prepare dinner. We are making your favourite dish!” 

(3)

Parent: “Thank you for helping me get these veggies clean for our dinner tonight!”

(4)
